ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good

This course helped me develop science communication skills through writing weekly synopses and two research papers, as well as a presentation. I gained a lot of knowledge on a variety of neuroimaging techniques.
I learned about various neuroimaging techniques, such as NMR (fMRI, MRS), PET, electrode-based (EEG, MEG, etc.). I improved my scientific writing ability.
Lots of practical knowledge about neuroimaging techniques and different ways they're applied.
Learned a lot about multiple neuroimaging methods, how to write a scientific paper, and to discern the most critical information from a text
A strong foundation of major neuroimaging techniques as well as writing and presenting skills.
I learned not only about tge fundamentals of neuroimaging, but also how ti he an active listener during presentations and how to give presentations myself. This class helped me grow.
I was able to develop an understanding of different neuroimaging techniques and their different applications in the field.
I learned a lot about fMRI and the thoughts required to create a study. In addition this class teaches you to write succinct synopsis of class material

General information on neuroimaging techniques, principles, and the clinical discoveries surrounding them.
Presentation skills, particularly for longer duration presentations (1.5 hours as a group, 20ish minutes personally)
Paper writing, continued to strengthen and exercise it from previous education and courses.
Neuroimaging vocabulary, writing skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Restrict the course to upperclassmen in order to facilitate learning and skip over basic concepts that took up a lot of the course time explaining to underclassmen and non-biological majors. Include more Professor-led lectures rather than purely relying on students to teach. Course would be much more beneficial in a seminar format. Grading should also be standardized by the teacher, rather than switching between TAs per week/assignment. Optimal class would be a professor-led lecture on course content followed by a student led presentation of relative research reports and papers related to that lecture. Again, smaller class size and heavier professor involvement with greatly improve the course.
Good

As a writing credit, this is on the lower workload side (in terms of amount of writing), which is appreciated because the content can be pretty difficult for nonBME majors (and thus may take more time to look over lectures and recordings to understand the content). It would be nice if the profs all did 30 minute mini lectures before the student lecture presentations instead of the students mostly teaching the whole course because it comes off as the professors interjecting only when questions are asked, rather than sharing the most important points of the weekly topic.

The weekly synopses are a strength of the course as they ensure the students are focused and fully understand the lectures. However, the deadline was usually three days following the lecture, on a Saturday evening. I would consider this a weakness as the assignment felt rushed sometimes so that I could be available for other responsibilities over the weekend.

Strengths: great professors and interesting lectures, especially since students put together presentations for some of the lectures. Weaknesses: the midterm / final essay are much more stringently evaluated than the synposes.

The material was interesting and useful, but for smaller details, I liked the group project aspect of the course. Having snacks each class was a really generous thing to do from the professors! Being able to revise our midterm papers for the final was also really nice.
Student-led presentations makes the class more engaging during your presentation, but content can be hard to follow depending on the topic

Strengths: The material covered in the course is very relevant to many disciplines. It is clear that all of the professors are experts in their fields and it was very cool to learn from them. 
Weaknesses: The organization of this course really made it hard to fully appreciate the material.

Weakness: student taught, so quality of lectures are not the best; workload of weekly synopsis was mostly set to 1.5-2 pages a week as opposed to the one page shown on the syllabus.
Strengths: pretty chill otherwise, no exams
I enjoyed the upper level feel of this class.

The topics of this course are quite intriguing. Despite only meeting once a week, I felt as if that was an appropriate amount of time to review the material. One strength of the course is it being hybrid and the lectures being recorded. As for weaknesses, I can't think of any.

Asking us to write consistently was a really good way to exercise writing, which is useful within this course, other courses, and in general. Many other classes don't require as much and it's easy to let that skill slip.
Course instructor was fabulous!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Good
Good writing credit, but the content may not be the most interesting for everyone. Teaching engagement varies because each lecture (after the third one) is taught by a group of 3-5 students.
I would recommend this class to any student where neuroimaging would be an area of substantial interest in their career or if they wanted a very science-oriented writing credit.
Yes! For people getting into the medical realm who are planning to carry out things like fMRI, this class actually felt really practically useful. Also a nice writing cred for stem people.
It was pretty interesting with managable workload-so probably yes if they are interested in the topic
I would recommend this course if they really want to learn more and need a writing credit.
Yes! I loved this class. But only take it if you are reallyy interested in neuroimaging.

I would recommend this course to another student at Yale. As a STEM major, this course is interesting and a great way to complete a writing credit. I hate writing and this course allowed me to enjoy it.

Yes, this helps develop writing skills in the field while also serving as a refresher and/or rounding out general knowledge in the area, as some of us are better educated in the clinical side, physical side, biology side, etc.
Yes!
